docs.lead_paragraph: A day after Republican Congressional leaders broke off budget talks with the White House, President Clinton sought to portray himself as the conciliator, saying he would keep the door open to a deal that "is clearly within our grasp right now." In a brief appearance at the White House, Mr. Clinton emphasized his points of agreement with the Republicans on dollar amounts of spending and tax cuts, and offered to postpone debate on policy differences until the fall elections.

headline.main: Clinton Urges Budget Talks To Continue

docs.snippet: A day after Republican Congressional leaders broke off budget talks with the  White House, President Clinton sought to portray himself as the conciliator, saying he would keep the door open to a deal that "is clearly within our grasp right now."     ...

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton and seven of the Republicans who want his job outlined starkly different proposals today on Medicare, Social Security and other issues of particular concern to elderly people. In written responses to questionnaires from the American Association of Retired Persons, six of those Republican candidates for President -- Lamar Alexander, Patrick J. Buchanan, Robert K. Dornan, Steve Forbes, Phil Gramm and Richard G. Lugar -- said the Government should let the elderly obtain health insurance through medical savings accounts.

headline.main: Clinton and 7 G.O.P. Candidates Make Their Appeals to Elderly

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re "Managed Care Has Trouble Treating AIDS, Patients Say" (front page, Jan. 15):

headline.main: When AIDS Patients Confront the Managed-Care System

docs.snippet: To the Editor:         Re "Managed Care Has Trouble Treating AIDS, Patients Say" (front page, Jan. 15):

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN it comes to public policy, does anyone listen to economic experts anymore? Judging from the rise and fall of the Clinton national health care plan -- the Edsel (this is the 90's: make that the "Waterworld") of public policy rollouts -- the answer is discouraging. And economists may have only themselves to blame. Indeed, economic professionals appear to pay little attention to the most knowledgeable people within their own ranks. That's the bleak message from Victor R. Fuchs, a health care economist at Stanford University and the departing president of the American Economic Association. He tackled the subject last week in his farewell address at the association's annual meeting in San Francisco. And while his words are hardly cheerful reading, Mr. Fuchs touches sensitive points that economists can ignore only at their own peril.

headline.main: Economic Scene;When economists talk, few listen if the subject is health policy.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your Jan. 15 front-page article mentions Gov. George E. Pataki's plan to force H.I.V.-infected Medicaid recipients into managed care. This would be a step backward.

headline.main: When AIDS Patients Confront the Managed-Care System

docs.snippet: To the Editor:         Your Jan. 15 front-page article mentions Gov. George E. Pataki's plan to force H.I.V.-infected Medicaid recipients into managed care. This would be a step backward.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: For people with H.I.V.-AIDS, a new social Darwinism seems to be exhibiting itself. The educated, reasonably healthy, aggressive people can get adequate care with health maintenance organizations -- if they know how to fight for it. But many do not have the energy or skills for beating the system. Instead of providing H.I.V.-positive people with tools to guard their health, many systems are geared toward evading them altogether.

docs.lead_paragraph: A commission appointed by the Republican leadership in Congress endorsed the idea of a flat tax yesterday, but ducked proposing anything specific. That allowed the commission to accentuate the positive, sidestep the negative and give voters a distorted prism through which to view its idea. A flat income tax would replace the current code's escalating schedule of tax rates with a single rate for rich and poor families alike. It would simplify business and personal tax forms, tax consumption rather than investment and wipe out special-interest loopholes that have poisoned the attitude of millions of Americans toward taxes.
